commentBody:
Now that was a reasonably Saturdayish puzzle!

Nice to see you back, Josh!
This is one of the hardest crosswords I‚Äôve tried in a long time. I mean, I‚Äôm not great at them, but I can usually get to halfway without help.  Reckon I got 5 clues this time!
Huh, I'd never thought of LOX on latkes. Lox on bagels, yes; latkes get sour cream (or plain yogurt) or applesauce. But it doesn't sound bad, so maybe I'll try it...
Tough but doable. Loved the fill. Always need help with names. Thanks, Josh! Have a great weekend, y‚Äôall!
This puzzle met its match with me. I was happy to see Rachel REID there, as I'm approaching the end of book 5!
I'm curious if you scored every NYT daily as it were made or Scrabble tiles if this would be the winner.
Fun puzzle. Took me a couple passes through to get a decent toehold, but after that it fell more quickly that I expected.
Proper Saturday difficulty, and an enjoyable puzzle altogether. Thanks.

After my first pass through I was at ROCKBOTTOM, but after patiently plugging away, a word here, a letter there, I got it together, and was EXHILARATEd (nice stacked pairing by the way).  All the Ks, Qs, Vs, Xs, Ys and Zs were fun. Delightful Saturday, tough but fair.
I was convinced I was going to fail at this one right up until I didn‚Äôt. A great puzzle!
Found it much easier than yesterday‚Äôs but more fun too. My 1000th puzzle according to the app!

Great Saturday puzzle. The northeast corner was a nightmare for me. I had KIMONO for the slip-on clue and nothing was coming together. Once POSSE occured to me, TSQUARE popped right out and everything fell into place. Ashamed to say I couldn't intuit TSQUARE without the T and the S. My late crossword-loving grandfather was an architect.

Hope we don't have to wait another 10 years for a new puzzle from this constructor.
I had to look a few things up.  It was a slog for me, but it's good to know that some puzzles will still be a bit difficult, after an easier than average week.

Any puzzle that takes me longer than my average for that day of the week is a great puzzle in my book - so thank you!!

I felt lucky to know 2D right off, having looked it up only yesterday in a failed attempt to prove an author* wrong for not using Abigail as the name of John Adams‚Äôs wife (middle name omission threw me). 

*in the book ‚ÄúThe Rebel Romanov: Julie of Saxe-Coburg, The Empress Russia Never Had‚Äù, by Helen Rappaport - a fascinating read for a Russian history NOOB such as I.

Finally. A good hard Friday. 

Also found the hardest Monday. 9/1/14. 

Good luck and don‚Äôt tell me about it. 

Another side note, there‚Äôs no blog about the mess of 9/11/14.  It was painful.
This is in no way, shape or form proper Saturday difficulty, but that's a losing battle

Oof, this one taxed me.  Wasn't sure I was going to get this one done without some lookups, but after rethinking some mistakes in the NW it eventually fell into place.  Better than my Saturday average but not by much, and the average is nothing to write home about anyway.  Toughest puzzle in a while for me.
It took me one hour and eight minutes but I solved it with no lookups and I really really didn't think I could do it. Just got lucky I guess.

I thought this was a decent proper Saturday! I was quite EXHILARATEd. 
I had OPENBARS before EXORCISE too.
TIL about BODYHORROR that was new to me!
Grateful to KHAN and Sidney LUMET for giving me footholds.
Great misdirects and clever clues‚Äîsmoking spot, key changes, free spirits and more.
Please, more of these!

Big thanks to Josh and Will for the first puzzle in recent memory that really made me think.

I didn't enter it, but my first thought for "Right, right, right" was LEFT

I question the clue for UNDID - yes, it works, but one can also undo a mistake (and I would argue that's the more likely case), so clues like "Rectified" or "Fixed" also work and IMO work better.

Super fun. Great way to start the weekend!

There‚Äôs a fire in the wood stove and the kids should be back from night skiing soon. Hot snacks and drinks are ready.

Now that was a proper Saturday. Tough, meaty, and plenty of misdirects to keep my head proper itchy. 

Took me the better part of an hour, but entirely gettable without lookups.

I had MORTADELLA in 17A for the longest time, and the double BB on 1D was throwing me for six. 64A was great, shoutout COD Zombies for helping me snag that immediately. Didn‚Äôt love 19A, but I‚Äôll let it slide as the rest of the puzzle was intelligently assembled. Brava.

So, POP QUIZ reminded me of a logic paradox.
Professor comes to the logic class on Monday and says, ‚ÄúWe will be having a POP QUIZ this week. I won‚Äôt tell you which day, and I promise it will be a surprise.‚Äù
The enterprising student thinks for a minute and says to himself, ‚ÄúWell, it can‚Äôt be on Friday because if it hasn‚Äôt come by Thursday, then we will know it must be on Friday so it won‚Äôt be a surprise. But on the other hand, now that we‚Äôve deduced that, then we also know it can‚Äôt be on Thursday, because if it hasn‚Äôt come by Wednesday and we know it can‚Äôt be Friday, then we will know it must be on Thursday and it won‚Äôt be a surprise. I can extend the same argument to Wednesday and Tuesday‚Äîtherefore there‚Äôs no day it would be a surprise and the professor must be lying!‚Äù
So the student smugly deduces, and doesn‚Äôt study. Of course, Thursday comes around and the professor says, ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs that pop quiz I promised!‚Äù And, sure enough, it was a surprise!

13 Down, I was shocked to find I don‚Äôt remember ever hearing the term ‚Äúcar share‚Äù and then still not understanding because ‚Äúkey changes‚Äù probably aren‚Äôt that common. ‚ÄúKey exchanges‚Äù probably more common. But ok you got me, I was even trying to decipher ‚Äúcar‚Äôs hare‚Äù for a minute there.
now that's what I call a saturday puzzle!

I liked this one and not just because it featured a Nova Scotia author at 41 across. I couldn't complete the puzzle until I gave up on the possibility of a cow producing 200 pounds of milk fat annually. It sounded plausible to me.

This was what I wanted, a puzzle that was tilted enough, inventive enough, and funny enough to keep me guessing and laughing.  Fixed a mistake (thanks, Caitlin) and I was done.

Good job, Josh.  Don't stay away so long next time!
For whatever reason, even when I finished the puzzle with PIX in 19A, I could not parse ADEXEC until I read Wordplay. Weird when the brain does that.  Nice chewy, tasty, puzzle.

This marks the end of the NYT crossword as we know it.  I went on at some length but it's been embargoed by the E.M.U. filter.

A sad day.

A lot of the people will be very happy with this puzzle because it is a "proper Saturday" due to the difficulty, but I did not like it. Almost half of the fill was not fun at all. It was drab. Too dry. Way too boring. A challenging puzzle can be fun as well, but this wasn't. I won't call a Saturday good just because it was hard, it also needs to have interesting entries.

I did notice the METHANE crossing with TOXIC GAS, but that did not incite any joy after the juiceless grind.

@Sam L @The X-Phile @SBK @dutchiris Mann on Jeopardy Final Jeopardy tonight (Friday at least on my TV) asked about the Swiss town featured in Mann's The Magic Mountain. The contestants in this Invitational event were all winners of multiple Jeopardy competitions. Not one knew Davos! A soup√ßon of smug is justified. Btw, I tried a search to find medical input on the treatments for tuberculosis described in the book. I found this article by a doctor who not only addresses that, but also talks in detail about what happened to Mann when he visited Frau Mann at a sanitarium much like The Berghof. There is a lot more discussion on the literary aspects. https://utppublishing.com/doi/pdf/10.3138/cbmh.6.2.147

userLocation: Spring Hill, just south of Armageddon
commentBody:
And all is right with the week.

Hats off to "Free spirits?"

Clue of the (weak) week.

Peace out.

I never thought I'd feel this way, but after all the cyber ink spilling arguing about the difficulty of puzzles, I really miss the arguments over the plural of octopus.

I thought this was a reasonably tough puzzle.  It took me a shade over an hour, which is two or three times as most Friday/Saturdays have been lately.

Was there ever a grid that told a solving story so well?

BLANKSTARE . . .MYSTERYBOX.
NOFUN!
ROCKBOTTOM.

GRIT!!!

TRY STARTERKIT . . .TSQUARE . . .

UNDID LOX . ..ISEE!!

POPTAB - EXHILARATE!
JIGS!
SOAR!
NICE.


[and a bonus AESOP tale:  TEXMEX TOXICGAS METHANE]
Before I INCUR the wrath of emus and KHAN. . .ZIPIT and off to REM.

Happy weekend solving!
I greatly enjoyed seeing all the Xs pop up in my answers today. It felt like a fun, subtle theme.

To become a soda manufacturer, you'll have to take a pop quiz.

(Don't worry, you'll Crush it!)
The more Xs and Qs I was putting in, the more I was sure I was messing up. But nope. Just a good, sweat it out puzzle.

I'm definitely not a chemist, nor do I play one on tv, but on my first time around, I plopped METHANE in at 36A. My second time around, I took it out, chiding myself that it couldn't be measured in pounds, surely not! I replaced it with milkfat. Ha! Oh well, it worked itself out, though the upper left was my slowest spot. 

Felt tougher than we've been getting, so that was good. Finished in about average time. 

Got a kick out of EXORCISE (though I was hoping there were come complimentary martinis around), QUESADILLA, ROCKBOTTON, POPQUIZ, and MYSTERYBOX. 

My energy has now officially hit ROCKBOTTOM for the day and week, so I'm going to say g'night!  But I am happily doing so because I got my big work project done this morning and have happily turned it over to the next stage!!!  Woohoo!!! I'll think about catching up on everything else another day. 

Now where's that free martini!?
Can NYT start another forum for everyone who wants to post to complain puzzles being easy and/or uninspired? Let the grumps have their own turf please!
Just happened to have this puzzle‚Äôs number, which is nice for a Saturday. Like Goldilocks‚Äô B&E, this one was just right.

I‚Äôve looked this puzzle up and down like three times and I‚Äôm not seeing a W. Am I missing it, or did Josh really get 25/26 of the way to a pangram and not cross the finish line? Enjoyable puzzle, nonetheless!
11 down sums it up

I found this very hard yet ultimately doable without lookups - at over 43 minutes this was my longest solve in weeks, and quite a bit longer than my Saturday average. Initially I had very little in the grid - the SW was first to fall, with much effort, then the NE, the SE after that, and finally the NW. I needed to take a break and let my mind reset to deal with the latter. Most of my entries started out in digital pencil - I was sure of very few things. There were just so many unknowns in the grid for me: LOUISE, New ERA, the Bay of Angels, "The Fisherman and his flute", the topic of Yom Kippur, TSQUARE, chakra locations, Rachel REID and "Heated Rivalry", Mercury of PHX, NYS, ARLENE, and the Chinese symbol of prosperity. Then there was stuff that would have stumped me not so long ago, since I only learned about it from NYT puzzles: LOX and IPHOTO. I had no idea whyd "Clip-on mic, for short" solved to LAV. So far in my experience that word has only been clued as a bathroom. However, for once an unknown of mine was covered by the column - quite the surprise! So yeah, for me this was a proper Saturday challenge. I wonder if EXOTICA even exists any more. In my "communist" era childhood anything from outside the Eastern Bloc was exotic: jeans, oranges, Marlboros, VHS tapes, and so on. These days I can buy anything online... And now for something completely different: Lucek the Poodle would like you to paint him like one of your French girls: https://imgur.com/a/VDVCbYK

Only disappointed that Right, right, right didn‚Äôt solve to left. 

An excellent puzzle. Only gimmes were AESOP and VESPA (the latter only because I used to go around on one). 

Liked MESA for flat earth. 

Thanks

It appears my treatise on hydrogen sulfide has fallen a fowl of the emus, so you guys lucked out on that one.

The main point is that rotten eggs are bad, but even a trivial exposure of pure H2S is very scary.  The smell is so profoundly horrible, especially knowing it's in the similar to hydrogen cyanide in toxicity.  

Bad stuff.  Very bad stuff.

And yet so close to water:  H2S is hydrogen sulfide, H2O is water.
This puzzle wasn‚Äôt difficult enough !!  I solved it in eight minutes with one hand tied behind my back and both eyes closed !!  When will we finally get a real Saturday puzzle ??
Sin is a core Christian concept. Jews don‚Äôt believe in sin.
That was fun!

For me any puzzle that has KHAN as an answer as in ‚ÄúThe Wrath of‚Äù  or the original Star Trek series is a good puzzle.  Solved it a bit faster than my average for Saturday but not by much.  The south west corner fell last especially when I worked out it was EXOTICA not ErOTICA!   What was I thinking?
Contrived clues.
The gold medal goes to REID for the gay hockey romance novels. üè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåàüá®üá¶ Go Canada!
I had ‚ÄúPoker-faced‚Äù instead BLANKSTARE, ‚Äúwily‚Äù instead of FOXY, some of the most disastrous wrong turns since the Archduke‚Äôs chauffeur took an erroneous route in Sarajevo 1914
My first thought for "Certain slip-on" was BANANA, and the first N worked with NOFUN, so I had it in there for a while.

Second puzzle in a row where the clues were either easy or just kind of off. Lots of ? style clues where the solution isn't a good misdirect, just an odd turn of phrase. Wasn't the worst, but didn't find a lot to love here either

Coincidentally, I just finished a Josh Knapp Saturday from 11/24/2012, It also used MESA and AMBLEd as answers, which may have helped me slightly with today‚Äôs solve, but with different cluing. My time was slower on the archived puzzle, but I found them both to be enjoyable challenges.
I liked it

I found this to be a properly challenging Saturday.  My first real toehold was in the SW, and that let me work counter clockwise around for a finish in the NW.  Between LOUISA, ARLENE (can't stand Garfield), KHAN, ERA and NYS (I thought that one would be a particular agency), I needed the TEAM portion of TRIVIA TEAM to get me away from thinking about answer keys.  That opened the whole corner up for me.  

Thank you, Josh.  Don't be a stranger.
11 Down: like this puzzle
Hello, Saturday!  Welcome back!  Bide-a-wee, will you?
Wowee that was a tricky one

Great puzzle!
Thought I had no chance after the first pass.
Very nice, satisfied feeling (a little fist pump) after completing it in 45 minutes.
Good one! I had almost nothing on my first pass, and was thinking ‚ÄúOK looks like it‚Äôs payback time for all the ‚Äòthese puzzles are too easy‚Äô complainers.‚Äù  But it turned out to be doable!

In previous constructors‚Äô notes, Josh focuses on changes he made in drafts to improve his puzzles.  He‚Äôs not a ‚ÄúThis is good enough‚Äù type of puzzle maker, rather, he sets a high bar and sticks to it.

Look at today‚Äôs puzzle, so polished in answer and clue.

I‚Äôd like to think he didn‚Äôt succumb to making this a pangram, by changing LAV to LAW (the puzzle is only missing a W), as that would have made a wince-worthy cross ‚Äì OWER.  I‚Äôd like to think he decided to opt for solver experience over pangram glory.

A  lovely crop of vague clues today, making many answers un-slap-downable.  Clues like [Campaign leader, informally], [Certain slip-on], and others.

This engages the brain like a playground engages the body.  

There's also feel-good.  Wordplay such as [Free spirits?] for EXORCISE, and beauty in answers such as BLANK STARE, TACIT, EXOTICA, EXHILARATE, AMBLE, and IRONCLAD.

Just a prime Saturday by a talent who puts in the work.  Thank you for a splendid outing, Josh.
It went pretty smoothly after I reluctantly concluded BANANA wasn't a certain slip-on.

Lox on a latke?

Next you'll be telling me you put apple sauce on your everything bagel!
(Just because they call it "everything" doesn't mean you can put everything on it!)

Today‚Äôs poem is a rhymer. Made from the words in the clues and answers to today‚Äôs puzz.

a/ is it just a fly you say
do angels look to look away
and you can fly and you can play
the quiet in the low
d/ when dreamers surreptitiously
think the moon prosperity
might they together set it free
you see that might be a/ dope

NICE.

Even if I *really* wanted
to find a W somewhere on the grid
(so close!)

and for
[Free spirits] to be 
open bar.

But a splendid Saturday.
One of the best puzzles in a LONG TIME, thanks!

Now that seemed like a solid Saturday puzzle to me! Solved it without assistance, but took me more than 30 minutes. Remarkably interesting fill---full of uncommon letters and unusual letter patterns---and some very some clever clues too. Especially liked "Free spirits?" for EXORCISE. A winner of a puzzle. Thanks.

Finally some weekend crunch. I smiled when I entered QUESADILLA as that was my childhood nickname that has stuck (my maiden name is similar). Two of my email addresses incorporate it. ELK, MESA and PHX reminded me of Arizona where we have a vacation home. METHANE and [Hydrogen sulfide, e.g.] led me to think about SIBO which I‚Äôve been learning about. I had quite a few misdirects that I had to correct along the way which I haven‚Äôt had to do in quite some time. I solved this right at my average time for Saturday. Thank you, Josh, and don‚Äôt be such a stranger!

And ‚Ä¶ there it is, as expected, the end of my 7-day streak. üòû Had no shot at solving this one, of course.  I had maybe 1/3 filled in and hit a wall. Turned on autocheck to find many wrong ‚ùå answers. But at least all the old timers won‚Äôt cancel their subscriptions now. Congrats üéâ to all who solved it in what ‚Ä¶ 10 minutes?

If you don't usually do the Newsday Saturday Stumper, today would be a good time to start. Rafael Musa is the constructor, and it's nice but pretty easy by Stumper standards. For the first time ever, it took me less time than the NYT. https://brainsonly.com/global/netword/cwd/#/s/260221

I needed the TRIVIA TEAM for this one.
Took a while to work from 'poker faced' to BLANK STARE.

Next up, QUESADILLAs for lunch.
LAV gave me OVER which begat ROLL and we were off.  A NICE one today.  Thanks.

Just when I think I‚Äôve got the hang of each day in crossword land, a puzzle like this says ‚Äòhold my beer‚Äô and wipes the floor with me.

I could not get a toe hold anywhere. I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôve had to go straight to Wordplay to even get started before. Other than PUNS, AESOP and LUMET everything else I tried was a big fat no. 
Finally, with a great deal of help from Ms Lovinger and your good selves I struggled to the finish line. Phew. Not complaining though; it was so full of interesting stuff, with more TILs than I can count that it was a thoroughly EXHILARATING excursion. Once I‚Äôd remembered how to spell the above that is. I always forget the H.

I‚Äôm running the bar at the Hall tonight while we show the Men‚Äôs Curling Final. Waving the flag for England üè¥Û†ÅßÛ†Å¢Û†Å•Û†ÅÆÛ†ÅßÛ†Åø Let‚Äôs hope they perform better than last weeks Rugby.
Pssh! 200 pounds is child's play.

To me, late week crosswords are one of the strongest reasons to *not* make complex decisions late at night.

Why?

At midnight, my neurons are firing at least 50% slower than during the next morning. This is a scientific fact.

Point in case, I started this gem and AMBLED about with an unsteady gait, making little to no progress. I peacefully closed the app after hitting (and acknowledging) the mental wall.

Cut to this morning, and the veil had been lifted! The puzzle fell with hardly an iota of resistance (is that one ohm, or two?)

In summary: when it comes to crosswords, or any other cognitive task, *sleep on it*!

I have no idea what BODY HORROR is, but it sounds even more horrible than plain old vanilla HORROR -- which I never watch or read or anything.¬† So once I had BLANK STARE, I wondered for, like. forever what B HORROR was.¬† I was sure I'd have to look up the L wife or the A cat, but as it turned out, I never¬†did.

I scampered away from the diabolical NW and entered at LUMET -- a name I actually did know.¬† I had trouble everywhere and my solve took forever.¬† But I prevailed.¬† The cluing was wicked.¬† Great clues for TRIVIA TEAM, EXORCISE, EXOTICA and CAR SHARE.¬† But I found easier answers like GRIT, INCUR, TACIT and EIGHT hard to get too because of how they were clued.

I have no idea what a MYSTERY¬†BOX is -- even though I ran the¬†Mystery Guild Book Club a long¬†time ago.¬† I wasn't wild about the clue for I SEE.¬† And I didn't know that FORK could be a verb or an adjective -- to me it's always been a noun.

ROCK BOTTOM line:¬† I struggled!¬† I suffered!¬† I liked it!

Quite difficult! As ever. Don't know why METHANE was the first clue I got.

I appreciate the clever clues even when  don't have a chance of solving them, like EXORCISE and PONCHO. I liked the uncommon ASUNDER.

I'm puzzled by the remarks made about POP QUIZ - it's not a reference to pop music? Why is it a surprise?

Never seen a MYSTERY BOX, a QUESADILLA, BBQ PIT or eaten a latke, or LOX for that matter (smoked salmon, yes) but it's all learning,

YAAAY, at last a puzzle appropriately difficult, and still I got it (which truly came as quite a surprise). Every new solve now extends my streak record... a streak really does motivate you to stick with a puzzle you might otherwise quit on.

Many commenters are applauding how difficult this puzzle was compared to more recent ones. I'm relatively new to solving, having started about a year ago, and I found this puzzle to be one of the easier Saturdays, solving in two-thirds of my typical time without any lookups. Perhaps I was just on the right wavelength today!

I really enjoyed the use of Q, X, J, and Z throughout the puzzle, which is perhaps what helped me solve more quickly; when in doubt, I decided to try an atypical letter!

Very enjoyable puzzle, with lots of fun clues that did misdirect me a few times and gave me chuckles when I figured out the correct answer.
There's TOO MUCH trivia in this puzzle! And the trivia is in spheres foreign to me, so I'll have to look up a helluva lot, or actually quit and do something productive with my life!

Welp....the NE got me.  I am grateful that I sussed out most of this very challenging puzzle.  (I did think to myself, "Don't I recall this Josh Knapp guy?"...and a shiver went down my spine.)

I took out POSSE and put it back a couple of times, 
Couldn't let go of POLO.
FORK for "split in two" was pure evil.  I had ORAL and ELK, but it just wasn't enough to tip me off.
I finally looked up the author.  (I had already had just a ton of fun with 30D, starting with SCALE MODEL, then STARTER SET.)
I do protest PEA as a stand-alone; "avocado" does not need "green" added to it, but PEA...!  No fair.
Ultimately I looked up 11D, and that unlocked the final set of entries.  I'll have to settle for being proud of getting the majority of the super-tricky puzzle as I go about my day....

Wow, Josh.  Hang this old white head on your trophy wall and smirk at it often.
Did anyone else have FINGER for ‚Äúyou might hear a hiss when it‚Äôs pulled‚Äù?
Anyone else want 1A to be POKERFACE?

Great puzzle! But lox as a topping for latkes? We cook up a lotta latkes every year at our holiday party. Served with apple sauce and sour cream, but I never knew people put lox on them. If it's really a thing, I'll have to try it.
A handful of Xs, two Qs, multiple Vs, Ys and a Z. Every letter but W. Bravo, Josh.
Misdirection, tricky crosses, what‚Äôs not to love? And somehow clocking in well below average - how‚Äôd that happen? Thanks for the fun!
Haven‚Äôt even finished the puzzle but wanted to give a shout out/congrats to Rachel Reid for making it into the crosswords universe! This fellow Canadian is proud!!!
Guess the ‚Äòeasy‚Äô comments from Valentine‚Äôs Day hit a nerve. This one was extra crunchy. I just want a puzzle that‚Äôs just hard enough for me to solve without hints and feel accomplished :)
Never heard of that movie genre but I guess that‚Äôs my only real beef. I was just about to begin the lookups when the SW corner fell. Nice challenging Saturday.

Sidney LUMET was a gimme. Along with the fantastic film in the clue, some other all-time favorites of mine of his of course are Dog Day Afternoon, Network, and Running on Empty.

And one movie I don't think I've heard of until moments ago: Child's Play.

So you all just had to complain about how easy the puzzles were this week, huh?

I guess you got your wish today.

Actually, it started out hard for me, then a bunch of the downs helped be gain a foothold on the acrosses, so I was surprised to see the progress notifications pop up.

What really killed me was the NW corner. Even after I got QUESADILLA I don't know enough about Instagram, so I stuck with a final S for way too long, and I've never heard of BODYHORROR, so the combination was challenging.



Almost seven minutes above my average.

When I was in junior high, our science teacher would play the music from "Close Encounters of the Third Kind" to signal that we were going to have a POP QUIZ. Oh, that feeling of dread as you walked to class.

I have no idea why EIGHT is a "symbol of prosperity" in China, and I lived there for a year. I thought ten was the most auspicious number - Taiwan Independence Day is celebrated on 10/10. I was amused to see that Chinese are putting up pictures of Draco Malfoy, because ma fu means "horse fortune."

A puzzle packed with sneaky, crafty clues and unusual letters, everything but the W, if I'm not mistaken, makes for a great Saturday puzzle!  This one took some thinking and some help from my husband, the Gameplay column, and the comments, but was doable.  I guess after more than a year of consistent crossword solving I am getting better, not necessarily smarter, but better and more willing to know when to look things up.  I'm okay with that now.  :-)
 Happy weekend and solving, friends.
To make this a pangram, 18A could have been WORK, changing 11D to NO WIN (and 21A to PINS).
Delightful! So many high value Scrabble tiles ü§£

How ‚Ä¶ (genuine question) did the Heated Rivalry clue get in there? Based on past Constructor‚Äôs Notes I sort of assumed the puzzles were typically written months and months in advance of publication, which means that extremely topical pop culture/current event trivia doesn‚Äôt have enough lead time to be included. And Heated Rivalry didn‚Äôt really enter the zeitgeist until maybe mid-December? I guess that‚Äôs enough time ‚Ä¶ or do editors sometimes update clues opportunistically?

I tried to see what would happen if I fed ChatGPT crossword clues. I gave it the clue and the number of letters. Here are a few of its first tries.
After 288 easy hours of solving, I completed the task. Curious and masochistic, I decided to see if ChatGPT would do better. In each case I gave it the clue and number of letters. The first results: 
Look to give nothing away: UNHINTING
European city on the Bay of Angels: NICE
Film genre exemplified by ‚ÄúThe Thing‚Äù or ‚ÄúThe Fly‚Äù: BODY HORROR
Like some fixations: ORAL
It gets folded and pressed: NEWSLETTER
Split in two: RENT
Posts on Insta: ADS

This proves something, but I don't know what. That's why I'm asking all of you.

I rarely post, so I hope Josh is reading this. This is hands-down one of the best puzzles I have experienced, and my most favorite Saturday puzzles of all time. It was a rightful Saturday, IMO - one where you at first feel the puzzle is disjointed and unwieldy, with very little filled in. Then, when you stick with it, and discover also that the Shortz editing wand has bestowed its wizardry, it all magically comes together. Thank you, Josh, for restoring my faith in the Saturday puzzle. You (and Will) have created a masterpiece.
The Saturday challenge I've been waiting for -- thank you!!!
I had to deal with a hydrogen sulfide incident in the lab this week. Not fun. This puzzle, on the other hand, was exhilarating!

Took 25% longer to solve than my average, and loved every second of it.
I long for challenging puzzles like this, that have me going through a mini-hero's journey of struggles, and triumphs, and red herrings, and re-considerations of my intelligence and self worth.

I hope solvers who prefer easier puzzles can forgive my excitement. This was the first puzzle in awhile where I couldn't solve it in a straightforward march through the clues with most of my solve occurring in my second pass through the Acrosses. Very predictable. 

Today's solve was about as far from predictable as one could get for a themeless.

My pathway was loopy. I wish I could draw the most fun one because I think it would have formed a rather elegant baroque design. The access I eventually found into my mostly blank NW started from 30D STARTER KIT but did not progress to AESOP at 29A. Instead it veered eastward to 34A and 39A, then northward up to 12D in the far reaches of that quadrant, then back down to 25A, then back up to 21D, and then back down to AESOP. Finally it found its way up into the NW, continuing to switch between downs and acrosses. 

I am dizzy.

My time was several multiples of the mean at XWStats, as it often is, but I enjoyed every moment.

Yesterday I complained about the easiness of end-of-the-week puzzles. 

Today, I compliment. This was a very worthy Saturday. Keep 'em coming!

When I started the puzzle, I could hardly find any ‚Äúgimmes.‚Äù I thought, ‚ÄúOh good, all the commenters will finally stop saying that the puzzle is too easy.‚Äù 

But then, as I worked on it a little, things started to fill in. A newbie (six months doing puzzles again), I felt proud of myself. I got most of the puzzles, with a little help from google. Yay! 

One clue about the Fisherman and his Flute fable kind of puzzled me a little though. I easily filled in AESOP, but I had never heard of that fable. With a little research, I found out that the story is about a fisherman who tries to get the fish to dance by playing his flute. When they don‚Äôt dance, he catches them in his net and tells them: ‚ÄúYou see, you refused to dance. And now I will watch you dance as you are succumbing in my net.‚Äù 

A little gruesome, but to me a little obscure. I‚Äôm not sure what the ‚Äúmoral of this story‚Äù is. 

Wikipedia seems to explain it but it‚Äôs still not clear.  

The Fisherman and his Flute - Wikipedia 

‚ÄúIn this context the fable is given the political meaning that those who refuse a benefit when it is first offered will gain nothing by acting as asked when constrained to.‚Äù 

What???? 

Any English majors around to explain? 

By the way, La Fontaine, very popular in France, also has a version of this story. Five hundred years ago, he was an attorney, but then became a storyteller in the king‚Äôs court. Many of his fables have interesting legal themes and morals from law.

"OMG, I didn't know Rachel Reid wrote so many other books!" he said. "Who's Rachel Reid?" I asked. "She wrote that book about the gay hockey players, which has just been filmed as a movie--it's really big news." "Well, everyone loves a Hockey Boy, but sounds like milking the cash-cow to me." https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fSR17d2GtGM&list=RDfSR17d2GtGM&start_radio=1 Ferda!

I'm sure most of you have smelled a rotten egg, so you know what hydrogen sulfide, H2S smells like, kind of.

But have you ever been in a lab in which H2S is being generated?

Holy smokes it is awful!  It smells black.  It smells like death.  Which makes sense because its toxicity is comparable to hydrogen cyanide.

The human nose is astonishingly receptive to H2S.  I've heard we can literally detect a couple dozen individual H2S molecules.

If the H2S concentration gets high enough, it overwhelms the receptors and you stop smelling it or anything else, even as you keep breathing it.

And oddly, H2S is almost water:  change the sulfur to an oxygen, and we have good old H2O.

@Fredegunde

No one says that you couldn't put LOX on a latke if you so desired, or that no one has ever done it in the history of humanity.  Sure, people put peanut butter on an onion bagel, too, but that's just as ridiculous.  Even ketchup on eggs seems relatively normal compared to either of those.

The point is, the two are not a known pairing.  Melissa Clark, being a food writer, would naturally have a tendency to try unusual combinations, but as a crossword clue, it's the kind that's off rather than just misleading.

Putting LOX on a latke seems weird because you're unlikely to be holding a latke in your hand like she's doing and eating it like an open-faced sandwich.  They're a bit oily, and you wouldn't like that sensation.

It's as if the constructor (or editors) said, "Here's a Jewish food.  How can I clue it with another Jewish food?"

A joke in a similar vein:

A lazy professor realizes that the final exam of his class is today, and he hasn't yet written the test.  So, he goes into the class and writes on the blackboard, "Formulate a question that summarizes the major points we have examined in this class, and answer it."

The students all get busy, writing and writing.  But one student casually turns in his blue book in just about a minute.  The professor asks, "Are you sure you're done?"  And the student says, "I'm pretty confident that I've satisfied the requirements.

Shaking his head the professor examines the blue book.

For the question the student wrote, "Formulate a question that summarizes the major points we have examined in this class, and answer it."
For the answer the student wrote, "Formulate a question that summarizes the major points we have examined in this class, and answer it."

The professor gave him a B+.

@Andrzej

I've been trying to read you, to tell if you are baiting me or not.

I mean, you do have a point.  Hydrocarbons and carbohydrates do both have carbon, but they have quite different properties (though, as Nora correctly said, there are a number of similarities between the two classes of compounds, as well).

On the other hand, I think you know that I know that.  

So I'm going to punt and say that the problem is the definition of "close" when it comes to chemical properties.

I think of H2S and H2O as "close" because they have very similar geometries, the only difference being a sulfur nucleus (plus its core electron) in the place of an oxygen.  Moreover, oxygen and sulfur are quite "close" in the periodic table.

I think we've succeeded in creating the most boring thread yet in this forum.

@Francis

I'm not baiting you. It's just about the divide between a specialist and a regular person. I don't care about the inner structure of chemical substances - all I'm interested in is how stuff works in my life: what it's good for.
